{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3714253,"name":"Carlos Salazar","username":"StarbuckBarista","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/starbuckbarista/{size}/186251_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-14T20:07:06.603Z","cooked":"

Hello everyone,

Our school recently opened a secondary campus dedicated to making STEM coursework more accessible to students, and we’ve been looking for ways to strengthen our robotics pipeline. Along with adding new engineering courses for middle school students, the administration is working to launch an FTC team and would like our FRC team to help support it.

We already have strong backing from the administration and several experienced faculty members, so I’m not too concerned about running the team day-to-day. What I’d love to hear is advice from FRC teams that already mentor or collaborate with FTC teams…

How do you approach the transition between FTC and FRC to best prepare students for success at the high school level? What have you found most effective in building skills, maintaining student engagement, and ensuring that the pipeline naturally flows into your FRC program?

Thanks in advance!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-08-14T20:07:06.603Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":16,"reads":211,"readers_count":210,"score":197.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":505303,"topic_slug":"transitioning-from-ftc-to-frc","display_username":"Carlos Salazar","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57451,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming & Electrical Captain"},"post_url":"/t/transitioning-from-ftc-to-frc/505303/1","custom_user_title":"Programming & Electrical Captain","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3714272,"name":"Dan Peled","username":"Dan1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dan1/{size}/268085_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-14T20:31:23.261Z","cooked":"

For me atleast the experience was;

  • start by explaining the differences in how the season works
  • changes in drive team terms (robot controller, driver station)
  • Differences in software and physical hardware - WPILib, command based, CANBus, radio
  • Write basic robot / give newcomers a basic system on the off-season robot (if there is one)

Most students that were serious about the team in FTC usually stay serious about the team in FRC, I don’t think I’ve seen any exceptions to that in my team

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-08-14T20:32:26.179Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":179,"readers_count":178,"score":80.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":505303,"topic_slug":"transitioning-from-ftc-to-frc","display_username":"Dan Peled","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":67107,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9738 Software Lead"},"post_url":"/t/transitioning-from-ftc-to-frc/505303/2","custom_user_title":"9738 Software Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3714667,"name":"Peyton Yeung","username":"Peyton_Yeung","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peyton_yeung/{size}/4840_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-14T22:04:14.020Z","cooked":"

We run the pipeline (FLL → FTC → FRC) with most of our FRC kids having done one of our other programs. In general, we run our FTC program in a similar manner as our FRC program but with 7th-8th graders instead of 9th-12th graders.

Parallels
Robot(s) designed in Onshape → This creates a fundamental understanding of spacial design planning. Not every FTC kid we have does CAD but neither does every FRC kid we have. This gets them familiar with CAD so they are better prepared when they move up to FRC.

Robot built in Robits → Our FTC teams do a hybrid build of custom machining, 3D printed components, and Robits as a build system. We like the hybrid aproach as we get some experience with machining and printing but also can leverage a build system approach for general assembly and traditional mechanisms. We use Robits as it is designed as system to bridge a gap between FTC and FRC. #10 hardware and half inch increment spacing is pretty standard in FRC builds so having that in an FTC build system makes the change over pretty easy.

Coding in Java → We use java for FTC as well as FRC. While they currently have a fair number of differences between the programs, we are expecting with the joint control system they become quite a bit more similar. This should make the move from FTC to FRC a bit more seemless.

Other stuff
Our junior high teams often get mentored by our high school kids. I think it’s worthwhile for the younger kids to see what they have to look forward to and the older kids can often have a older sibling level effect.
Speaking of mentorship, all of our FTC mentors also play some part in working with our FRC team so their are a lot of friendly faces for the kids moving up.

Overall, I’d say a majority of our FRC leadership kids were on one of our FTC teams and got pretty hooked. The closer the programs operate, the easier the transition is from one to the other.
